conclusion: Analyze the motion of the positively charged ball under the influence of both the electric field and gravity.
Consider the forces acting on the ball, the trajectory, and the change in electric potential energy.
The ball experiences two forces: gravitational force and electric force.
Since the ball moves in a straight line at an angle to the opposite direction of the electric field, the net force must be along this direction.
Components of forces perpendicular to the trajectory must cancel each other out.
Break down the forces into components along the direction of the trajectory and perpendicular to it.
The component of the gravitational force in the direction of the trajectory is mg sin θ.
The component of the electric force in the direction of the trajectory is qE cos θ.
For the ball to move in a straight line, qE cos θ = mg sin θ.
The electric potential energy change is given by the work done by the electric force.
The work done by the electric force is W_e = qE x.
The distance traveled in the direction of the electric field when the ball reaches the highest point is x = (v_0^2 sin^2 θ) / (2g cos^2 θ).
Calculate the change in electric potential energy: ΔU_e = -qE x.
Substitute qE and x to find ΔU_e = -m v_0^2 sin^3 θ / (2 cos^3 θ).
The difference in electric potential energy of the small ball when it reaches the highest point compared to its electric potential energy at point O is -m v_0^2 sin^3 θ / (2 cos^3 θ).
